article.headline: Arizona 80, Arizona State 70
article.story: TEMPE, Ariz. (AP) -- Hassan Adams did what he does whenever Arizona needs a spark -- take charge. He did it again against rival Arizona State. Adams had 21 points and six of Arizona's 10 steals, leading Arizona to an 80-70 win over the Sun Devils on Wednesday night. "We just got comfortable and ran our stuff," said Adams, who rallied the Wildcats from an early cold spell and kept them in front with 11 points in the second half. "We got a lot of nice, open looks, we kept fighting on the boards and we got control." Mustafa Shakur had 17 points, Ivan Radenovic scored 13 and Marcus Williams had 11 in the victory, Arizona's 21st in 22 games against the Sun Devils. The Wildcats (13-6, 6-3 Pac-10) won their third straight. "I thought Arizona's veterans stepped up and played really well for them, especially Hassan Adams and Mustafa Shakur stepped up and made plays when they needed them," Arizona State coach Rob Evans said. "Hassan Adams in a stretch took over the game, and their veterans played better than our veterans." Kevin Kruger scored 23 points and freshman Jeff Pendergraph had 17 points and 11 rebounds, the first double-double of the season for Arizona State (7-11, 1-8). Bryson Krueger scored his 14 points in the second half. But they didn't come quickly enough for the Sun Devils, who have lost eight of their last nine. The Wildcats opened a 41-28 lead on a 6-0 spurt by Radenovic in the first 2:46 of the second half -- kicking off a half in which Arizona shot 62.5 percent (15-of-24). "I think it was just coming out with a lot of confidence," Shakur said. "We've had some games where we felt bad, but we were in the gym all the time working on it, and we knew they would start to drop." Arizona State missed its first six shots of the second half, but still had a realistic chance against the more athletic Wildcats with 16:15 to go, when Williams fouled Serge Angounou, sending him to the foul line, and then protested enough to draw a technical foul. Arizona coach Lute Olson then drew another technical. But with the potential for six points and the ball, the Sun Devils got three -- Angounou missed both free throws before Kruger made three of four. Kruger also hit a 3-pointer 10 seconds later, and Arizona State closed within 41-34. But Adams responded with a 3-pointer. He also made a 19-footer, two free throws and dunked, giving Arizona a 63-47 lead with 6:54 remaining. "Hassan had another great game," Olson said. "The last five- or six-game stretch for him has been possibly the best he's played since he got here." The Sun Devils started well, taking a 13-4 lead a 3-pointer by Kruger 4:05 in. But Pendergraph picked up two quick fouls midway through the first half, going to the bench with nine points and six rebounds. That took the pressure off Arizona's Kirk Walters, who had four of his career-high five blocks in the first half. Shakur scored 11 points in the half, the first three on a putback on which he was fouled with 15:24 to go. That got Arizona within 13-7 and started a 16-4 run that sent the Wildcats into the lead for the rest of the game. "We're upset with ourselves," Pendergraph said. "We keep losing games because of the things we do ourselves."
